ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about trans studies and expanded my skillset in reading and engaging with difficult gender studies material. I learned a lot about trans people, who they are and aren't, who they might or might not be, and how they figure in and influence the world. I have an enhanced understanding of what transgender could (and should) mean, and a heightened appreciation for the complexity of this discipline. Loved everything I read and appreciated the intense challenge the material and subject-matter presented. Also appreciated the opportunity to learn in this important setting.

Lots about the the trans studies canon, with special attention paid to race and intersectionality as well (more than I expected). As someone who has taken a lot of ER&M classes but never a WGSS or comparative class on gender or sexuality studies, it was a little intimidating keeping up, but I'm glad I did it because I've walked away with so much. Prof. LaFleur and Olivia were generous, too, about explaining things and meeting you where you are.
This class taught many of the central tenets of trans theory. We considered many different aspects of the field, and focused especially on the work of doing trans theory.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was very eye-opening, especially for someone who had never taken a higher-level course like this before. The syllabus was great, and Professor LaFleur was a fantastic lecturer. However, it's definitely not an introductory class, and I would caution against taking it unless you have taken a 200-level WGSS class before.

Strengths: great readings, great Prof (& TA!), great convos with the class, great films and books (especially "Paul" & the Mock, "Disclosure" and anything Spade or Namaste).

Weaknesses: some readings (Snorton) were intensely difficult; reading load was tough every week; writing is difficult to do when you're not very experienced in writing in this discipline.
This course is incredibly strong -- the readings especially were excellent!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course did a good job at hosting a good conversation between the students, however it was difficult at times--due to the nature and complexity of the material--to hold a really really good conversation where everyone understands everything being referenced.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. I think that trans studies is a very vibrant and up and coming field, and Professor LaFleur is great. Even though it's a lot of work, it's definitely worth it in the end.

Yes, of course. It's a challenge and one you should take if you're interesting in understanding how the world became and becomes what it is (generally) as well as how trans people figure in and influence the world (specifically) and how trans studies mediates an important conversation about the (bad) state of the world and its (bad) history.

This class is wonderful! Discussions were insightful, thoughtful, and interesting. The essays and novels we read will stick with me for a long time. This class and Professor LaFleur inspired a whole lot of thinking in and out of the classroom.
Yes! The work's a little dense if you're not familiar with WGSS or trans studies, but altogether so useful in any ER&M/WGSS/etc. analytic you take up.
Absolutely -- would recommend this class to every student at Yale. It has fundamentally changed the way I see myself, the world, and gender.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live seminar once per week; not recorded.
